text: i prefer strong type language as it is easy to refactor
<@U12452RAP>  - well we are happy to have you create an SDK in a strongly typed language  :wink:
<@U0PB67X4K> yep, I created a java SDK early by myself. However now there is already a proposal, I think I can help on that.
nodejs 7.0 will release soon, maybe we should change callback to async/await then
I think we should definitely move to nodejs 6.0 as the minimum version we support
and leverage es6 and other new features to simplify things

"move to nodejs 6.0 as the minimum version we support” - I thought about this, it would give us native Promise and class construct. I already use Promise natively, thinking if users complain about the newer node.js version it requires, we can easily paddle back by requiring “bluebird” and we don’t have to change the code. but if we adopt the class support in ES6, then it’s whole different code we’d have to write compared to what I rolled in base.js, with .extend(). if users complain then it’s a lot of work to move off of ES6 class support
guess the question is node.js 6 adoption rate
well I can be convinced of support either v4 or v6 as the minimum requirement as both are the LTS versions with v4 being supported until April 2018 and v6 supported until April 2019
so no need to continue supporting v0.12
but v6 makes more sense to me as a corporate person as I'd get 2 years of support from the time V1 fabric releases
btw here’s the versions supported by bluemix as a reference point: <http://semver.ng.bluemix.net/node/versions>, latest is 6.6
<@U0Z81GL6S> <@U0MRPSV45> <@U1KFBBWG1>  <@U1L2C9F3R> I think we are good to go wrt Gari’s suggestion of moving to node.js 6+. I’ll start changing the code to use the “class” construct
